title: Peru: Citi Announces 10 Winners of Eighth Annual Microentrepreneurship Awards
summary: Lima - The Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards are the flagship initiative of the Citi Foundation, emphasizing the importance of micro-entrepreneurship and microfinance in financial inclusion processes and the socio-economic empowerment of low-income individuals. The program was launched in 2005 and is now offered in 36 countries, which use the awards to recognize the contributions of microentrepreneurs and microfinance institutions to the local economy. This year, the Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards, organized by Citibank Peru in partnership with the IPAE business school, honored 10 microentrepreneurs from around the country.
tag-1: Peru: Citi Announces 10 Winners of Eighth Annual Microentrepreneurship Awards
tag-3: Lima – The Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards are the flagship initiative of the Citi Foundation, emphasizing the importance of micro-entrepreneurship and microfinance in financial inclusion processes and the socio-economic empowerment of low-income individuals. The program was launched in 2005 and is now offered in 36 countries, which use the awards to recognize the contributions of microentrepreneurs and microfinance institutions to the local economy. This year, the Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards, organized by Citibank Peru in partnership with the IPAE business school, honored 10 microentrepreneurs from around the country.
tag-4: The awards included a total of US$36,000 in cash prizes, with $3,500, $2,000 and $1,000 awarded to the first-, second- and third-place winners in each category, respectively, along with a trophy and diploma. The winner of the Excellence Award received $5,000, a diploma and trophy, as well as a scholarship to the EMPRETEC workshop for SMEs.
tag-5: The competition's top honor, the 2013 Excellence Award, went to Janette Karol Villena Bendezú, a microentrepreneur from the region of San Martín whose business, Agro Oriente Viveros SAC, was nominated by Crediscotia. Agro Oriente is dedicated to the cultivation, production and sale of ornamental plants using environmentally friendly methods. The judges noted its organization, vision and mission to develop tourism-related activities and promote environmental conservation.
tag-6: The award from Most Innovative Financial Institution went to FONDESURCO, which received two scholarships to attend the Boulder Institute of Microfinance's well-known Boulder MFT Microfinance Training Program for Latin America and the Caribbean in 2014.
tag-7: Since 2005, the Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards have invested more than $300,000 in prize money and benefited more than 90 microentrepreneurs, giving them the resources to make significant progress in developing their businesses.
tag-8: "The Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards recognize the importance and contributions of microfinance in economic development and poverty reduction," explained José Antonio Blanco, General Manager of Citibank Peru. "They promote financial inclusion for microentrepreneurs."
tag-9: This type of program is fundamental for Peru, which ranked first in the world in the development of microfinance for the fifth year in a row, scoring 82.5 out of 100 in the Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU)'s 2013 Global Microscope Index on the microfinance business environment.
tag-10: Peru also participated in a regional workshop in Buenos Aires to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards at the global level. Winners and finalists of the 2010, 2011 and 2012 awards from Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Guatemala, Paraguay, Peru and the Dominican Republic attended. Representing Peru was Martina Mamani, the winner of the 2011 services award, for the inn she runs out of her home in Cuzco.
tag-12: Production: First place in the Production category went to Estanislao Valenzuela (Junín), nominated by Caja Huancayo. Valenzuela invented a potato-slicing machine he sells to restaurants. He has plans to patent his invention.
tag-13: Second place in the Production category, and the award for innovation, went to Orlando Garay, nominated by Caja Sullana. Garay creates unique jewelry out of gold, silver and other metals and trains his employees to prefect their technique.
tag-14: The third-place winner was Leoncio Tinoco (Junín) a client of Caja Huancayo. His best-known product is Tapiz Artesanal, wall hangings and tapestries made out of unspun wool finished to look like an oil painting. His production has helped attract tourism to his community in cooperation with Tinkuy Perú.
tag-15: Service: The first-prize winner in the Services category, and the winner for innovation, was Behcer Escobedo (Junín). His business, sponsored by Caja Huancayo, organizes eco-tours and raises exotic butterflies, bringing tourists in contact with nature and raising environmental awareness.
tag-16: In second place, Benjamín Quispe (La Libertad), nominated by Financiera Proempresa, owns a rural restaurant that specializes in trout he raises on his own fish farm.
tag-17: The award for third place went to Flavio Martínez (La Libertad), nominated by Financiera Proempresa for his contribution to cultural development through his business renting rehearsal and recording space to low-income artists.
tag-18: Commerce: In the Commerce category, Jesús Rojas (Lima), a Financiera Proempresa client, won first place for his business selling domestic and imported shoes. Rojas was a traveling salesman for many years until he and some partners opened their own store.
tag-19: Second place went to Raúl Huanaco (Puno), presented by Caja Los Andes for his efforts to raise and sell Suri Alpacas. He has plans to expand internationally and the judges praised his business plan.
tag-20: Finally, third place honored Martín Pacohuanaco (Tacna), another Caja Los Andes client, who buys and sells pregnant livestock and their milk. His ability to diversify his business has contributed to its profits.

tag-23: The Citi Foundation The Citi Foundation is committed to the economic empowerment and financial inclusion of individuals and families, particularly those in need, in the communities where we work so that they can improve their standard of living. Globally, the Citi Foundation targets its strategic giving to priority focus areas: Microfinance, Enterprise Development, Youth Education and Livelihoods, and Financial Capability and Asset Building. The Citi Foundation works with its partners in Microfinance and Enterprise Development to support environmental programs and innovations.
